title: Resources
text:
Week 5: Observable JS and jQuery
For Week 4 I spent some time on the chalkboard and showing demos in the browser, as ‚Äúsidebars‚Äù to the main content in the slides, so I wanted to share some of this sidebar material here!

ObservableJS

The ObservableJS demo I showed in class, originally made for a microeconomics course I TAed back in the day but relevant to you as DSAN 5200 students if you reveal the JS code ‚Äúbehind‚Äù each of the UI elements (the sliders in this case), and how changing some aspect of the data in these JS cells automatically updates the visualization to reflect these changes.
(For more of my Observable examples‚Äîas in, examples where I can therefore walk you through exactly how they work!‚Äîfeel free to look at some of the other notebooks in my ObservableHQ account from that same course, like this one)
More generally, though, ObservableHQ has a really rich set of tutorials covering a bunch of different use cases! At the bottom of that page, for example, you‚Äôll see some which are tailored specifically to Python and Matplotlib users.
One resource I remember helping me a lot was the official set of Observable resources on how inputs (sliders, checkboxes, etc.) work in OJS. To me this subtopic is especially helpful/fundamental since, once you see how data from the input elements (like sliders or checkboxes) flows into all other code cells which use this data as inputs, the notion of ‚Äútopological data flow‚Äù that I mentioned in class today will hopefully feel less abstract.
Lastly, though, if you‚Äôre like me and the weirdness around ordering of code cells in OJS feels very bizarre at first, I think this notebook is really really helpful for clarifying that in a way I didn‚Äôt have time to walk through in detail today. I basically keep that link open in a tab whenever I work in OJS, so I can go back and reference it when I get confused about why one cell ran before/after another.



jQuery

The jQuery website has a ‚ÄúLearn‚Äù section here. It‚Äôs probably overkill, though, since jQuery is so popular and widely-used (though, falling out of favor to some extent for various reasons) that you should be able to use Google and StackOverflow to find answers to most issues that will arise with learning the basics and then using it.

title: Resources
text:
Core Texts, Weeks 1-4

Wilkinson, The Grammar of Graphics (2006)
A key resource for the course, in terms of weaving many of the seemingly-disparate ‚Äústrands‚Äù of the course together, is Leland Wilkinson‚Äôs book The Grammar of Graphics (Wilkinson 2006). Since it‚Äôs extremely hard to find in bookstores and extremely large and difficult to carry around even if you do find it, for educational purposes you can access a PDF of the book using this link.


Nathan Yau, Visualize This! (2011) and Data Points (2013)
Another pair of resources that we‚Äôll be drawing on a lot throughout the semester! Way less technical than Wilkinson, and way easier/cheaper to find at bookstores or online, so I feel much less good posting this one online‚Ä¶ But if your situation is anything like mine was when I was a grad student, and you‚Äôre living off approx. $0 per month of disposable income, here are EPUB copies of both books (which I am ethically justifying by reference to grad-student-Jeff‚Äôs experience of professors assigning 5 books/week without a sole PDF or EPUB in sight üòµ, along with the fact that all 4 profs for the course are paid subscribers to Yau‚Äôs blog!)

Yau (2011): PDF, EPUB
Yau (2013): PDF, EPUB



Edward Tufte, The Visual Display of Quantitative Information (1983)
Tufte (1983) is (in my experience, at least) much easier to find than any of the books above, but in varying conditions of used-ness, so here is a PDF of this one as well.
(Tufte also has more books than the previous two authors, and any of them are interesting and informative, so if you like this one you can go out and buy/obtain the others as well!)

title: DSAN 5200: Advanced Data Visualization
text:
This page hosts Prof.¬†Jeff‚Äôs slides for Section 03 of DSAN 5200-03: Advanced Data Visualization, Georgetown University, Spring 2024. The section takes place on Tuesdays from 12:30pm to 3:00pm in Car Barn, Room 309. All other materials for the course can be found on the main course webpage!

Date

January 11

January 16

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: Key Point: Data Viz \(\neq\) Data Analysis
text:
Key Point: Data Viz \(\neq\) Data Analysis

Readers haven‚Äôt gone through the process of developing and answering questions that you went through in developing the viz
Your audience wants to know the story, result, and/or conclusions
They (usually) don‚Äôt want the messy details you trudged through when analyzing the data; that‚Äôs your job!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Different Approaches for Different Audiences!





Visualization for Analysis:


‚ÄúInternal‚Äù audience: You and your team (shared context)
Efficient understanding and iteration to develop insights
Rough drafts: Can make changes/‚Äúpolish‚Äù later




Visualization for Presentation:


‚ÄúExternal‚Äù audience: Content is likely new to them; audience has no context
Different info is useful to them vs.¬†useful to your teammates
Takes significantly more time to get to publication ready







From Chaos Theory: The Glorious Unpredictability of Young Thug, Jayson Greene, Pitchfork, 28 September 2015

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: What Does ‚ÄúDesigning For An Audience‚Äù Look Like?
text:
What Does ‚ÄúDesigning For An Audience‚Äù Look Like?

Explain the encodings
Provide context
Focus on readability
Develop aesthetics
Yau (2013), Ch. 6: ‚ÄúDesigning For An Audience‚Äù  (Georgtown Library Proxy Link)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Explaining Encodings

What scale are you using? What does that color represent? Is this normal?
Better to err on the side of too much explanation than too little
Too much? People can gloss over details (if designed well üòâ)
Too little? People unfamiliar with the visual encodings will get stuck














Figure¬†1: The Statistical Atlas of the United States, produced in the late 1800s by the Census Bureau, explained all of the encodings. For example, look at this bump chart from the 1880 atlas. It ranks cities by population.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: Explaining Things You Forgot You Need To Explain
text:
Explaining Things You Forgot You Need To Explain

When you work with a dataset for a while, it‚Äôs easy to forget that others aren‚Äôt as familiar [‚Ä¶] When you know all the intimate details, it‚Äôs hard to step back and remember what it was like when you first opened up a file or database‚Äîjust a bunch of numbers (Yau 2013, 209)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: Explaining Things You Forgot You Need To Explain
text:
Explaining Things You Forgot You Need To Explain

(If you know this video, don‚Äôt say anything!!)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Provide Context

When readers can decode the shapes, colors and geometries on your chart, you are more than half way there to producing an awesome chart.
However, readers also need to understand the context of the data.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: But How Much Context Do I Need To Provide?
text:
But How Much Context Do I Need To Provide?

An aside from the humanities (Gadamer 1960)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Readability

Charts should read like text! It should be obvious what the chart is about, how to interpret it

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Aesthetics

Default settings in viz tools are generic and designed specifically to work with as many datasets and visualization types as possible
This \(\neq\) best for your use cases!
You can (and should) develop aesthetics to make your charts less ugly
(Note: In this context, aesthetics means a visual style. Do not confuse this with the aes() call in ggplot2.)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Aesthetics: Broad Umbrella Term

Something like‚Ä¶ the gestalt sum of visual design choices


From Georgetown‚Äôs official color guide (but remember: color is only one of many factors that makes up an ‚Äúaesthetic‚Äù)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Aesthetics: Broad Umbrella Term

From Nicholas Felton‚Äôs 2014 Annual Report

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Guidelines, Not Rules!

They‚Äôre more continuous than absolute. Your charts may need more or less explanations, more or less context, etc.
Depends on your audience and the purpose behind your chart:

If your audience is a small group who has the same background as you, then you might not need to provide as much context for the data you show.
If your audience is already excited about a dataset, then you probably don‚Äôt need to make it too flashy.
If you make charts for a research paper, there are probably publisher guidelines that you need to follow, which limits what you can do (sometimes a good thing).

Think of the above adjustments as continuous knobs that you can turn up or down. The more charts you make, the better you‚Äôll get at deciding how much to turn.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Pre-Attentive Processing

The ability of the visual system to effortlessly identify certain basic visual properties.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Tamara Munzner




Computer scientist, info viz expert, and professor at University of British Columbia

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

Abstraction: Translate from the domain specifics to the visualization vocabulary

What is shown? ‚Üí data abstraction
Why is the user looking at it? ‚Üí task abstraction

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

Abstraction: Translate from the domain specifics to the visualization vocabulary

What is shown? ‚Üí data abstraction
Why is the user looking at it? ‚Üí task abstraction

Idiom: How is it shown?

Visual encoding idiom ‚Üí how to draw
Interaction idiom ‚Üí how to manipulate

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

Abstraction: Translate from the domain specifics to the visualization vocabulary

What is shown? ‚Üí data abstraction
Why is the user looking at it? ‚Üí task abstraction

Idiom: How is it shown?

Visual encoding idiom ‚Üí how to draw
Interaction idiom ‚Üí how to manipulate

Algorithm: Efficient computation

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: The What: Abstracting the Data

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Abstracting the Data

Why abstract the data?

Different attribute types different representations
Different dataset types different idioms available

What do you need to abstract?

Dataset type: (e.g.¬†table, network, temporal, etc.)
Attribute types: (e.g.¬†categorical, ordinal, quantitative)
Ordering direction: (e.g.¬†sequential, diverging, cyclical)
Data availability: (e.g.¬†dynamic, static)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Types of Datasets


(Also temporal!)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Tables

From Tidy data for efficiency, reproducibility, and collaboration, Julie Lowndes and Allison Horst, 12 October 2020

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Types of Attributes











Categorical: No order

Example: names, countries, types
Must be represented with visual channels that don‚Äôt convey order

Ordered

Ordinal: Has implicit order, but you can‚Äôt do arithmetic

Can be numerical (but should be treated as categorical)
Example: t-shirt sizes, grade in school, rankings

Quantitative: Ordered, and you can do arithmetic

Can be divergent or sequential
Example: age, temperature, earnings

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Ordering











Sequential: Infinite range with clear minimum

You can perform arithmetic
Example: age, number of goals, price
Must be represented with visual channels that don‚Äôt convey order

Diverging: Middle point + two opposite directions

Middle point not always zero
Example: temperature, earnings, political affiliation index

Cyclic: Cycle in the values

Starting point may not be obvious
Can be repsented w/cyclical channels
Ex: days of the week, hours in the day

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
The Why?
(More on this next week!)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: The How?

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Marks and Channels

Marks are geometric primitives:







Channels (encodings) control the appearance of marks

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Channel (Encoding) Types

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Points











Zero-dimensional
Convey position only
Additionally, can be size and shape coded

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Lines











One-dimensional
Convey position and length
Can only be width coded

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Areas











Two dimensional
Fully constrained

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Graphical Presentations of Relational Information





















Figure¬†2: Figures 14 and 15 in Mackinlay (1986)




Although encoding is often undertaken without much intention or deeper consideration, it has significant impact on the ability of the visualization to communicate knowledge accurately and efficiently.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Another Guide (Illinsky)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Position: Example 1
Position allows you to compare values based on where they are placed with reference to a coordinate system.



Considerations:

Be aware of the scales you are using (linear vs logarithmic)
The scale changes the interpretation of distance
It can also change the perceived patterns





Code
library(tidyverse)
set.seed(140)
d <-  data.frame(x = rgamma(15,1)) %>% mutate(y = 3 + 2*x + 5*I(x^2) + rnorm(15,3,3))
plt <- ggplot(d, aes(x, y))+
    geom_point(size=6) + 
    theme_bw() + 
    theme(axis.title=element_blank(), axis.text = element_blank(), 
          axis.ticks=element_blank())
plt + annotate('text', x=0.5, y=60,label = "Linear scales", hjust=0, size=8 )









Code
plt + scale_y_log10() + scale_x_log10() +
    annotate('text', x = 0.1, y = 50, label = "Logarithmic scales", hjust=0, size=8)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Position: Example 2
Position allows you to compare values based on where they are placed with reference to a coordinate system.


Considerations

Avoid overplotting since many points can occupy the same space and obscure one another

Solutions

Use transparency so that overlapping points make darker areas
jitter (add noise so points no longer are on top of each other)
Use binning to show aggregate data per pixel

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Length

Length is most commonly used in the context of bar charts. The longer a bar is, the greater the value.
Don‚Äôt truncate bar charts, use length in its entirety!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Angle

Angles range from 0 to 360 degrees in a circle.




Considerations:

Angles are most associated with pie charts. Pie chart is made up of parts that make up a whole.
Don‚Äôt use too many categories (bar chart is better)
The sum of all percentages should equal 100%!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Pls Don‚Äôt

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Slope

Slope is similar to angle. Line charts are the most common use of slope to encode data.
Considerations:

Slope magnitude: steeper = greater change, flatter = lesser change
Aspect ratio
Visual change should match the context of the change

Cleveland, McGIll & McGill (1988) suggested that the average slope in a line chart should be 45¬∞, in order to make neutral comparisons between lines (still a good rule of thumb)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Area




Like length, area can be used to represent data with size, but with two dimensions instead of one.
Considerations:

While the encoding might not be as precise from a visual perception perspective, area can provide a more intuitive, less abstract view for some types of data
Make sure you scale by area, not edge (remember, area gets squared per unit increase): This means you should encode the length of a side as \(\sqrt{x}\)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Volume




Volume can used in the same way as area (one more dimension)
Considerations:

Make sure you scale by volume, not edge (remember, volume gets cubed per unit increase)
This means you would encode the side of a ‚Äúbox‚Äù as \(x^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{x}\)

For 3-D encodings, you need to take volume as proportional to the data

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Color + Society = Meaning

Color is not ‚Äúsortable‚Äù in the traditional sense
However, color can convey implicit meaning!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Common color pitfalls

Encoding too much information or irrelevant information
Using nonmonotonic colors for data values
Failure to design for color vision deficiency
Not creating associations with color
Not using contrasting colors to contrast information
Not making the important information stand out
Using too many colors

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Color

Color as a visual encoding can be split into two categories: hue and saturation.
Hue: what most people refer to as color (red, green, blue, etc.)
Saturation: amount of hue in a color.
Qualitative: every color represents a distinct attribute (category)
Sequential: color represents a range (saturation) from low to high (or vice-versa)
Diverging: multiple hues represent a point of inflection of the data

text: Sequential Scale: Example 1

text:
Common Palettes


Most of these palettes are available to both ggplot2 and matplotlib. For R, you may have to load packages like RColorBrewer or viridis.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: Looking Forward: The Grammar of Graphics (GG)
text:
Looking Forward: The Grammar of Graphics (GG)

Cleveland (1985) lists the ‚Äúbasic elements of graph construction‚Äù as: scales, captions, plotting symbols, reference lines, keys, labels, panels, and tick marks.
Wilkinson (2006) built on Bertin (1967), formally defining components of a graphic:








Statement
Description




DATA
A set of data operations that create variables from datasets


TRANS
Variable transformation (e.g.¬†rank)


SCALE
Scale transformations (e.g.¬†log)


COORD
Coordinate system (e.g.¬†polar)


ELEMENT
Graphs (e.g.¬†points) and their aesthetic attributes (e.g.¬†color)


GUIDE
Axes, legends, etc.




Hadley Wickham implemented Wilkinson‚Äôs grammar in R via ggplot2 (more info)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Making Your Own Theme üòé

On GitHub

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
References


Bertin, Jacques. 1967. Semiology of Graphics: Diagrams, Networks, Maps. ESRI Press.


Cleveland, William S. 1985. The Elements of Graphing Data. CRC Press.


Gadamer, Hans-Georg. 1960. Truth and Method. New York: Crossroad.


Mackinlay, Jock. 1986. ‚ÄúAutomating the Design of Graphical Presentations of Relational Information.‚Äù ACM Transactions on Graphics 5 (2): 110‚Äì41. https://doi.org/10.1145/22949.22950.


Wilkinson, Leland. 2006. The Grammar of Graphics. Springer Science & Business Media.


Yau, Nathan. 2013. Data Points: Visualization That Means Something. John Wiley & Sons.

text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

Abstraction: Translate from the domain specifics to the visualization vocabulary

What is shown? ‚Üí data abstraction
Why is the user looking at it? ‚Üí task abstraction

Idiom: How is it shown?

Visual encoding idiom ‚Üí how to draw
Interaction idiom ‚Üí how to manipulate

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Nested Model Analysis Framework (Munzner)
Four levels, three questions:



Domain: Characterize the problems and data of a particular domain

Who are the target users?

Abstraction: Translate from the domain specifics to the visualization vocabulary

What is shown? ‚Üí data abstraction
Why is the user looking at it? ‚Üí task abstraction

Idiom: How is it shown?

Visual encoding idiom ‚Üí how to draw
Interaction idiom ‚Üí how to manipulate

Algorithm: Efficient computation

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: The What: Abstracting the Data

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Abstracting the Data

Why abstract the data?

Different attribute types different representations
Different dataset types different idioms available

What do you need to abstract?

Dataset type: (e.g.¬†table, network, temporal, etc.)
Attribute types: (e.g.¬†categorical, ordinal, quantitative)
Ordering direction: (e.g.¬†sequential, diverging, cyclical)
Data availability: (e.g.¬†dynamic, static)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Types of Datasets






(Also temporal!)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Tables



From Tidy data for efficiency, reproducibility, and collaboration, Julie Lowndes and Allison Horst, 12 October 2020

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Types of Attributes














Categorical: No order

Example: names, countries, types
Must be represented with visual channels that don‚Äôt convey order

Ordered

Ordinal: Has implicit order, but you can‚Äôt do arithmetic

Can be numerical (but should be treated as categorical)
Example: t-shirt sizes, grade in school, rankings

Quantitative: Ordered, and you can do arithmetic

Can be divergent or sequential
Example: age, temperature, earnings

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Ordering














Sequential: Infinite range with clear minimum

You can perform arithmetic
Example: age, number of goals, price
Must be represented with visual channels that don‚Äôt convey order

Diverging: Middle point + two opposite directions

Middle point not always zero
Example: temperature, earnings, political affiliation index

Cyclic: Cycle in the values

Starting point may not be obvious
Can be repsented w/cyclical channels
Ex: days of the week, hours in the day

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
The Why?
(More on this next week!)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: The How?

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Marks and Channels

Marks are geometric primitives:







Channels (encodings) control the appearance of marks

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Channel (Encoding) Types

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Points














Zero-dimensional
Convey position only
Additionally, can be size and shape coded

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Lines














One-dimensional
Convey position and length
Can only be width coded

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Areas














Two dimensional
Fully constrained

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Graphical Presentations of Relational Information





















Figure¬†2: Figures 14 and 15 in Mackinlay (1986)




Although encoding is often undertaken without much intention or deeper consideration, it has significant impact on the ability of the visualization to communicate knowledge accurately and efficiently.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Another Guide (Illinsky)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Position: Example 1
Position allows you to compare values based on where they are placed with reference to a coordinate system.



Considerations:

Be aware of the scales you are using (linear vs logarithmic)
The scale changes the interpretation of distance
It can also change the perceived patterns





Code
library(tidyverse)


‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.2     ‚úî readr     2.1.4
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.4.3     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.2     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.0
‚úî purrr     1.0.2     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
set.seed(140)
d <-  data.frame(x = rgamma(15,1)) %>% mutate(y = 3 + 2*x + 5*I(x^2) + rnorm(15,3,3))
plt <- ggplot(d, aes(x, y))+
    geom_point(size=6) + 
    theme_bw() + 
    theme(axis.title=element_blank(), axis.text = element_blank(), 
          axis.ticks=element_blank())
plt + annotate('text', x=0.5, y=60,label = "Linear scales", hjust=0, size=8 )









Code
plt + scale_y_log10() + scale_x_log10() +
    annotate('text', x = 0.1, y = 50, label = "Logarithmic scales", hjust=0, size=8)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Position: Example 2
Position allows you to compare values based on where they are placed with reference to a coordinate system.



Considerations

Avoid overplotting since many points can occupy the same space and obscure one another



Solutions

Use transparency so that overlapping points make darker areas
jitter (add noise so points no longer are on top of each other)
Use binning to show aggregate data per pixel





Warning: The dot-dot notation (`..density..`) was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
‚Ñπ Please use `after_stat(density)` instead.

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Length

Length is most commonly used in the context of bar charts. The longer a bar is, the greater the value.
Don‚Äôt truncate bar charts, use length in its entirety!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Angle

Angles range from 0 to 360 degrees in a circle.




Considerations:

Angles are most associated with pie charts. Pie chart is made up of parts that make up a whole.
Don‚Äôt use too many categories (bar chart is better)
The sum of all percentages should equal 100%!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Pls Don‚Äôt

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Slope

Slope is similar to angle. Line charts are the most common use of slope to encode data.
Considerations:

Slope magnitude: steeper = greater change, flatter = lesser change
Aspect ratio
Visual change should match the context of the change

Cleveland, McGIll & McGill (1988) suggested that the average slope in a line chart should be 45¬∞, in order to make neutral comparisons between lines (still a good rule of thumb)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Area







Like length, area can be used to represent data with size, but with two dimensions instead of one.
Considerations:

While the encoding might not be as precise from a visual perception perspective, area can provide a more intuitive, less abstract view for some types of data
Make sure you scale by area, not edge (remember, area gets squared per unit increase): This means you should encode the length of a side as \(\sqrt{x}\)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Volume







Volume can used in the same way as area (one more dimension)
Considerations:

Make sure you scale by volume, not edge (remember, volume gets cubed per unit increase)
This means you would encode the side of a ‚Äúbox‚Äù as \(x^{1/3} = \sqrt[3]{x}\)

For 3-D encodings, you need to take volume as proportional to the data

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Color + Society = Meaning

Color is not ‚Äúsortable‚Äù in the traditional sense
However, color can convey implicit meaning!

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Common color pitfalls

Encoding too much information or irrelevant information
Using nonmonotonic colors for data values
Failure to design for color vision deficiency
Not creating associations with color
Not using contrasting colors to contrast information
Not making the important information stand out
Using too many colors

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Color

Color as a visual encoding can be split into two categories: hue and saturation.
Hue: what most people refer to as color (red, green, blue, etc.)
Saturation: amount of hue in a color.
Qualitative: every color represents a distinct attribute (category)
Sequential: color represents a range (saturation) from low to high (or vice-versa)
Diverging: multiple hues represent a point of inflection of the data

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Sequential Scale: Example 1

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Sequential Scale: Example 2

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text: Divergent Scale: Example

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Common Palettes






Most of these palettes are available to both ggplot2 and matplotlib. For R, you may have to load packages like RColorBrewer or viridis.

text: Colorblindness

text: Color as Context

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
section: Looking Forward: The Grammar of Graphics (GG)
text:
Looking Forward: The Grammar of Graphics (GG)

Cleveland (1985) lists the ‚Äúbasic elements of graph construction‚Äù as: scales, captions, plotting symbols, reference lines, keys, labels, panels, and tick marks.
Wilkinson (2006) built on Bertin (1967), formally defining components of a graphic:








Statement
Description




DATA
A set of data operations that create variables from datasets


TRANS
Variable transformation (e.g.¬†rank)


SCALE
Scale transformations (e.g.¬†log)


COORD
Coordinate system (e.g.¬†polar)


ELEMENT
Graphs (e.g.¬†points) and their aesthetic attributes (e.g.¬†color)


GUIDE
Axes, legends, etc.




Hadley Wickham implemented Wilkinson‚Äôs grammar in R via ggplot2 (more info)

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
Making Your Own Theme üòé

On GitHub

title: Lecture 2: Visual Encodings, Integrity, Color Theory
text:
References


Bertin, Jacques. 1967. Semiology of Graphics: Diagrams, Networks, Maps. ESRI Press.


Cleveland, William S. 1985. The Elements of Graphing Data. CRC Press.


Gadamer, Hans-Georg. 1960. Truth and Method. New York: Crossroad.


Mackinlay, Jock. 1986. ‚ÄúAutomating the Design of Graphical Presentations of Relational Information.‚Äù ACM Transactions on Graphics 5 (2): 110‚Äì41. https://doi.org/10.1145/22949.22950.


Wilkinson, Leland. 2006. The Grammar of Graphics. Springer Science & Business Media.


Yau, Nathan. 2013. Data Points: Visualization That Means Something. John Wiley & Sons.

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Open slides in new window ‚Üí

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Storytelling with Data

Often, your jobs as a data scientist is to be an effective communicator
There is more to communication than numbers on a paper










Data stories appear to be most effective when they have constrained interaction at various checkpoints within a narrative, allowing the user to explore the data without veering too far from the intended narrative.

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
What is Data Storytelling?






https://venngage.com/blog/data-storytelling/

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Components of a data story

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Storytelling is abstract
It is not merely:

a technical matter of creating an image
designing the right chart


Rather it is:

the broader considerations that impact nearly every decision you make in the way you frame and present a project



The story is the culmination of distilling the information and insights gathered through the analytic process
It is often represented by a series of well chosen and developed visualization, but these visualizations reflect intentional design choices based on your understanding of the data, the story and your audience

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Telling Your Data Story
Story components
To tell a story you have to define a story

A story is how what happens affects someone who is trying to achieve what turns out to be a difficult goal, and how they change as a result


Plot: how the story unfolds
Protagonist: the main character
Problem: a difficult goal for the protagonist to achieve
Transformation - the ‚Äúso what?‚Äù: how the protagonist changes as a result

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Story linearity

Whether driven by time or logic, stories are typically is linear
Beginning, middle and end



















Every story is linear, with a well-defined beginning, middle and end. However, those pieces don‚Äôt have to take equal time.
Stories have pacing, which creates tension and interest, and makes the storytelling more compelling.

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Traditional vs.¬†Data Stories





source

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Aristotle vs.¬†Brecht

Sometimes you don‚Äôt want to ‚Äúresolve‚Äù the tension!
Aristotelian drama: audience goes home ‚Äúsatisfied‚Äù

The story is wrapped up, all of the loose ends are tied up, and everything resolves (whether in a happy or sad ending)

Brechtian drama: audience is left with discomfort, ambiguity, unresolved tension

Sounds like something you wouldn‚Äôt want to do (and you don‚Äôt, in many cases), but sometimes can be more effective for spurning people to action!

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Common visual narrative Genres

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Standard Infographics

An infographic is¬†a collection of imagery, data visualizations, and minimal text that gives an easy-to-understand overview of a topic.

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Data Infographics

Data infographics are infographics that rely entirely or mostly on numbers to tell the story. This often includes data viz, such as charts and graphs, but not always.

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Research posters

Even research poster construction requires a narrative flow!

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Scientific papers structure

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Developing knowledge content







Bill Shander talks about different levels of content engagement. We‚Äôll describe these in the next few slides

text: Primary communication tools

text: Engagement levels-1

text: Engagement levels-2

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Storytelling tips

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text: Author vs reader driven

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Repetition and Redundancy
The old adage on how to present anything:

Tell them what you are going to tell them
Then tell them
Then tell them what you just told them

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
Awesome data driven viz narratives

The New York Times
Wall Stree Journal
The Washington Post
FiveThirtyEight
The Economist
Financial Times
The Pudding

title: Lecture 4: Storytelling and Visual Narratives
text:
The Pudding‚Äôs process:

By Ilia Blinderman

Storytelling is complicated
Who is your audience
Focus broadly or narrowly
Complexity of the finding after analysis
Progressing through the arguments
Arriving at the conclusion




Resources
